Executive Summary



USS-POSCO Industries (UPI) has updated RMP submitted to EPA on August 18, 2016.  As part of this 5 year update, UPI has included the following:

- Following a significant incident at a source, the 5-year accident history information will be updated within

six months to reflect the incident.

- If the emergency contact at the source changes, the RMP will be updated within one month, to include the

new emergency contact information.

- The emergency contacts email address has been included in this RMP submittal.

- The purpose for the RMP submissions has been included 5year re-evaluation and re-submittal to EPA.

- Name, address, and phone number of the contractor used to complete the RMP submittal has been

included and updated due to office change.



Site Description & Regulated Substances

USS-POSCO Industries (UPI) is located at 900 Loveridge Road in the city of Pittsburg, California approximately

1/2 mile north of Highway 4. The UPI property occupies approximately 490 acres. It is bordered by the New

York Slough of the San Joaquin/Sacramento River on the north and by open space and industrial facilities in

all other directions. The nearest residences are located approximately 3/4 miles to the southwest of any

facilities handling chemicals regulated under the RMP Rule.



The plant employs approximately 640 people. The operating divisions within the UPI facility include: the Rolling

Division,  Sheet Division, Tin Division,  Reliability Division, and the Technology, Environmental & Safety Division.



Anhydrous ammonia and liquid hydrogen are the only two federally and state regulated substances present

at UPI.



Anhydrous ammonia is stored in liquid form, under pressure, in an outdoor 28,0000 lbs. supply vessel. The

vessel sits on a concrete pad that is surrounded by a locked fence.



The amount of ammonia stored in the supply vessel is less than 50% of the vessel capacity, by

volume. The management control to maintain this invent

ory is:

-Ammonia is ordered only when the tank volume is less than 15%.

-Ammonia supplier is contracted to only deliver tank trucks of 3,750 gallons.



These controls result in a maximum inventory ammonia inventory of 5,550 gallons (28,000 pounds at 25?C).

The threshold quantity for anhydrous ammonia is 10,000 pounds under the EPA RMP and 500 pound under CalARP.



The Hydrogen's largest vessel quantity is: 10,260lbs with a total of hydrogen on site to 15,930lbs (the sum of both

vessels). A low level alarm to alert both the Supervisor and Supplier that Hydrogen is needed is installed on the tank, and set to 3" W.C.



Management System:

UPI has developed a formal management system for planning, organizing, implementing and controlling the

risk management program elements. This management system is consistent with the recommendations

contained in CCPS Plant Guidelines for Technical Management of Chemical Process Safety. This management

system satisfies the requirements of the RMP EPA 40 CFR Part 68.15  and ensures that the risk management

program elements are developed, implemented, and continually improved. The management system

activities are further discussed below.

- Planning - UPI has an overall risk management program policy that clearly identifies the goals and objectives of the risk management program.

- Organizing - Individuals responsible for each risk management program element have been designated. These  individuals are responsible for developing and maintaining policies and procedures for each risk

management program element that meet program goals and objectives.

- Implementing - Detailed responsibilities for program implementation may be delegated to other individuals. Such individuals are trained on their responsibilities, and the corresponding procedures, before they are

allowed to perform their responsibilities. Strict adherence to procedures is emphasized. Refresher training is provided on an as-needed basis.

-Controlling - Member

s of management and the individuals responsible for each risk management prevention program element periodically conduct internal reviews or audits against the goals and objectives of the element. All records associated with the prevention program elements are retained for a minimum of five years unless otherwise specified in the RMP EPA regulation, to permit periodic, comprehensive audits. Weaknesses in

program elements, or in their implementation, that may be discovered during internal audits or reviews are corrected.

- UPI utilizes a shared drive to store all of its RMP and CalARP documentation. The UPI employees responsible for the Risk Management Program elements have access to the shared drive.  This shared drive has been instrumental in helping UPI keep all of the requirements in one location for our employees, via a secured shared drive with limited access.



Prevention Program:

Many of the processes, including the RMP covered processes are also regulated under the Occupational

Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, 29 CFR Part

1910.119. The release prevention program at UPI was developed to prevent onsite and offsite impacts to

people and the environment. Therefore, this facility has developed a release prevention program to comply

with both the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) rule and the OSHA PSM requirements. The release

prevention program includes the following elements: Management System, Hazard Assessment, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Pre Start Safety Review, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, Employee Participation, Safety Permits (Hot Work & Confined Space), Contractors, and Emergency Planning & Response.



The prevention program elements represent an integrated system of administrative controls intended to

ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment. Many of the

se prevention program elements

(e.g., PHAs, compliance audits, incident investigation) result in the development and implementation of

additional safeguards (i.e., administrative and engineering controls). These safeguards prevent, detect, or

mitigate the effects of accidental releases of regulated substances.



Employee training is also a major focus at UPI. UPI believes that employees who clearly understand how to

safely operate a process can significantly decrease the number and severity of incidents, and increase

efficiency. Therefore, a thorough training program focused on specific operating procedures and safe work

practices is a key element of our effective prevention program.



Employees involved with operating & maintenance of the process receive training on the hazards associated with the process, how to operate the process within safe operating limits, and how to handle potential emergencies. The training program satisfies the requirements of the RMP EPA 40 CFR Part 68.71. The training is comprised of the following:

- Initial all new employee awareness training.

- Operator & Maintenance personal training.

- Training provided in response to equipment or process changes, as identified under the MOC program;

-Periodic refresher training; and

- Training documentation.



All operators and maintenance personnel who work within the covered process receive initial training in safe work practices and basic operating principles prior to assignment.

The operators and maintenance personnel receive training specific to the operations of the process once they are assigned. Various means are used to verify competency, but primary emphasis is placed on on-the-job observation by supervisors. Documentation of the training is forwarded to the Safety Department for filing and tracking.

In addition to on-the-job training, UPI personnel are trained in basic safety courses on an ongoing basis. 



Emergency Response

UPI's Emergency Response team consists of Fir

st Responders, Emergency Response Team and Emergency Medical Technicians (EMTs).



First Responders are trained to be first on the scene and assist in the event of an emergency. First Responders attend monthly training to keep their skills current.



The Emergency Response Team consists of First Responders who receive more specialized, in-depth training including confined space rescue, hazmat training and firefighting. This group works with the UPI Fireman and EMTs on all phases of emergency response.



Emergency Medical Technicians are onsite 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Our certified EMT's duties also include emergency dispatch, rescue, medical treatment, patient transport, security and onsite training.



UPI conducts 4 emergency situational drills per month for emergency preparedness.  Some of the drills conducted include the Contra Costa Fire department in a continual effort to keep our close relationship with the outside agencies. 





Five-Year Accident History

A review of facility incident investigation reports has shown that there have been no incidents involving

Ammonia or other hazardous substances, for which the onsite or offsite consequences exceeded the

reporting requirements of RMP EPA, CFR Part 68.42.

Following a significant incident of a covered RMP process (anhydrous ammonia or liquid hydrogen), UPI will

update the accident history to reflect the incident. This is intended to help EPA and other agencies identify

the need for technical assistance, and a timely update to the accident history will provide information to

prevent  similar incidents in industry.  UPI saves articles of Ammonia incidents in the industry for the purpose of generating "What If" questions for the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) revalidation. 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The changes that UPI has implemented since the first submittal of the RMP in 1999 have resulted in a 26% decrease in the toxic worst-case scenario distance for anhydrous ammonia. Additiona

lly this distance reduction has resulted in a 46% reduction in the estimated residential population within the worst-case endpoint zone.

The liquid hydrogen process worst-case scenario does not result in any residential population within the

endpoint distance zone.



UPI Vision/Mission Statement:

THE SAFETY OF ALL EMPLOYEES IS OUR FIRST PRIORITY

We will achieve the best safety record of the steel industry.  Through benchmarking, "best practices" and root cause analysis; we will determine and provide the appropriate protective equipment, proper work environment and training to accomplish this goal.  We will audit activities and conduct drills to ensure compliance with UPI's safety program.  We expect all employees to take responsibility for their own safety, the safety of others, and be accountable for their own actions.



UPI has a long-standing commitment to business principles which promote the safe, ethical operation of its steel manufacturing facilities in Pittsburg, California. These principles have resulted in clear UPI business strategies that call for continual improvement of safety, quality, customer satisfaction, protection and preservation of the environment, and community responsibility. Implementation of, and adherence to, these business strategies requires the full commitment of all UPI employees. UPI continues to plan to improve safety by taking any incident related to the ammonia process, analyze it, and incorporate it into the training schedule we currently have.

Our Training programs continue to be improved and provided to all employees as a result of safe employees

and providing a safe environment.



UPI participates in the Ammonia Safety & Training Institute 8 hour Safety Days by sending members of the Safety Department and ERT's to this yearly events. 



We continue to monitor any changes in the regulations to ensure that we are continually improving and

implementing those applicable to our process.



UPI's Continuous Improvement to

the Environment (C.I.T.E) policy dictates that each division continuously identify methods to reduce the use of hazardous materials and to reduce the risk to the community and environment through implementation of inherently safer technology and procedures. 



UPI stresses safe and environmentally sound operations with communications to our employees.  UPI safety and

Environmental programs are included in the monthly safety meetings for all employees.  A  Joint Safety Committee comprised of both wage & management meet monthly to discuss all aspects of Environmental Health & Safety.  UPI supervisory and management personnel conduct periodic audits to ensure adherence of our safety policies and procedures including our strict Housekeeping policy.  Employees are required to get seven safety contact per months, which include recent  safety incidents, policy & procedures and observations.



UPI utilizes a "Plant Information Display Application" (PIDA) to communicate safety related items to our 640 employees.  The PIDA system is a close circuit system that displays safety information to 25 very large monitors installed in all areas of our facility.
